study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a method for identifying step-by-step kinematic parameters in Parkinson's disease (PD) patients and healthy controls using a short 5-meter gait assessment with a body-fixed sensor.
results_summary: The study found that the proposed method could reasonably distinguish PD-associated gait from healthy controls, with a discriminant model achieving 89.5% correct classification, 95.8% sensitivity, and 78.6% specificity. The results suggest short gait assessments may be clinically useful for PD detection.
population_specificity: 14 healthy controls and 28 patients with early-to-moderate idiopathic Parkinson's disease.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (gait assessment, not a supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of standard endurance and strength training (SET) versus medical Qigong (QG) on psychological functioning, quality of life, symptoms, and physical functioning, including walking distance, in patients with advanced cancer.
results_summary: SET was more effective than QG in improving perceived strength and walking distance, with a significant impact on exercise capacity. However, the order of interventions influenced outcomes, with reduced benefits when SET was administered second.
population_specificity: Patients with advanced non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) and gastrointestinal (GI) cancers receiving or eligible for chemotherapy.
effective_dosage: Supervised SET twice-weekly (specific walking dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of oscillatory whole-body vibration (WBV) in improving exercise capacity and quality of life in patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) on stable therapy.
results_summary: WBV significantly improved 6-minute walking distance, cardiopulmonary exercise testing variables, muscle power, and health-related quality of life compared to the control group. The intervention showed a net benefit of 39.7 meters in walking distance and substantial improvements in other physical performance metrics.
population_specificity: Patients with PAH (WHO-Functional Class II or III) on stable PAH therapy for ≥3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and cultural considerations of a minimally supervised, home-based exercise program incorporating walking for individuals with Parkinson's disease in Jordan.
results_summary: The intervention showed a high retention rate (86.7%) and adherence rate (77%), with improved UPDRS-III scores in the intervention group. Sociocultural barriers specific to Arabic culture were identified as potential challenges for program uptake.
population_specificity: Individuals with Parkinson's disease in Jordan.
effective_dosage: Not specified (home use of an exercise DVD, walking program, initial instructional sessions, and weekly phone calls by a physiotherapist).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of exercise training, including walking, in improving exercise tolerance and health-related quality of life in patients with very severe COPD.
results_summary: The study found that exercise training, including walking, significantly improved 6-minute walking test performance and health-related quality of life in patients with very severe COPD, with weighted mean differences of 67.1 meters and -8.041 points on the SGRQ, respectively.
population_specificity: Patients with very severe COPD (forced expiratory volume in the first second <35% of predicted normal value).
effective_dosage: 1 to 5 sessions per week, lasting 15 to 40 minutes each.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of autologous cell therapy for intractable peripheral arterial disease/critical limb ischemia, focusing on outcomes like amputation risk, wound healing, and survival.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that cell therapy reduced amputation risk by 37%, improved amputation-free survival by 18%, and enhanced wound healing by 59%, with no significant impact on mortality. However, efficacy was not significant in placebo-controlled trials or those with low bias risk.
population_specificity: Patients with intractable peripheral arterial disease/critical limb ischemia, particularly those ineligible for revascularization procedures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether effective antiretroviral therapy (ART) prevents developmental milestone delays, including walking, in HIV-infected infants compared to HIV-unexposed uninfected (HUU) infants.
results_summary: HIV-infected infants on ART showed significant delays in walking milestones (both with and without support) compared to HUU infants, with greater delays observed in those lacking viral suppression and immune recovery.
population_specificity: HIV-infected infants (initiated ART by age <5 months) and HIV-unexposed uninfected (HUU) infants.
study_duration: Follow-up duration not explicitly stated, but comparisons were made at 6 months post-ART.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify gait deviations associated with plantar heel pain by reviewing quantitative gait variables in affected individuals.
results_summary: The study found strong evidence that stance phase duration remains unchanged in individuals with plantar heel pain, but identified compensatory changes such as decreased rearfoot center of pressure duration and increased midfoot/forefoot contact time and impulse. Limited evidence also suggested increased medial forefoot and rearfoot mobility.
population_specificity: Individuals with plantar heel pain compared to asymptomatic cases or limbs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of a functional training program, including walking, on physical functioning in hip fracture patients during short-term stays in primary health care.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a functional training program to improve physical functioning, measured by the Short Physical Performance Battery (SPPB) and secondary outcomes like Timed "Up & Go" (TUG) and self-reported measures, but results are not yet provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients aged 65 or above who sustained a hip fracture, excluding those with severe cognitive impairment (MMS-E <15), inability to walk 10m pre-fracture, or terminal illness.
study_duration: During short-term stays at nursing homes post-hospital discharge (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review available information on idiopathic toe walking (ITW), including its prevalence, classification, and therapeutic approaches, and to differentiate ITW from tiptoe walking with neurological or muscle deficiencies.
results_summary: The review found limited research on ITW's etiology, prevalence, classification, and evaluation but consolidated existing information on these aspects and its treatment.
population_specificity: Individuals with idiopathic toe walking (ITW) and tiptoe walkers with neurological or muscle deficiencies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of three locomotor training methods (G-EO, Lokomat, and PBWSTT) on gait velocity and spatiotemporal symmetry in individuals with chronic traumatic brain injury.
results_summary: All three training methods significantly improved self-selected walking velocity, with Lokomat and PBWSTT also improving maximal velocity. The 6-Minute Walk Test improved for G-EO and PBWSTT groups, while the Lokomat group showed improvement in mobility domain scores. No significant changes in gait symmetry were observed.
population_specificity: 22 individuals with chronic traumatic brain injury (≥12 months post-injury) and hemiparetic gait, able to walk unassisted at 0.2-0.6 m/s.

study_goal: To evaluate the efficacy of functional electrical stimulation (FES) for improving gait speed in people with multiple sclerosis (pwMS) during short and long walking tests.
results_summary: FES showed a significant initial and ongoing orthotic effect on gait speed in short walking tests, with mean increases of 0.05 m/s and 0.08 m/s, respectively. No effects were observed in long walking tests or for therapeutic effects in either test type.
population_specificity: People with multiple sclerosis (pwMS) experiencing foot drop.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe brain MRI findings in individuals with dystroglycanopathies (DGs) and relate these findings to functional outcomes, including motor function and walking ability.
results_summary: The study found that 85% of the cohort achieved independent walking, but only 33% did so in the group with the most severe brain malformations (group 1). Walking ability correlated with the severity of brain imaging abnormalities.
population_specificity: Individuals with dystroglycanopathies (DGs) enrolled in a natural history study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a community-based lifestyle intervention, including walking, in increasing physical activity and improving dietary behaviors among Vietnamese adults with metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: The intervention significantly increased moderate intensity activity, walking, and total physical activity while reducing sitting time. Dietary improvements included reduced intake of animal internal organs and cooking oil usage.
population_specificity: Vietnamese adults aged 50-65 years with metabolic syndrome from Hanam province.
effective_dosage: Not specified (walking group participation included in the intervention).

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the relationship between resveratrol and breast cancer, focusing on its potential protective or harmful effects.
results_summary: The abstract discusses conflicting evidence regarding resveratrol's effects on breast cancer, highlighting variability in dosage, administration, bioavailability, and molecular traits of breast cancer subtypes. No clear conclusion is provided.
population_specificity: Not specified (abstract focuses on in vitro and in vivo breast cancer models).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the effectiveness of a telephone-delivered, pedometer-mediated walking intervention for improving pain outcomes and increasing walking among African American patients with chronic musculoskeletal pain.
results_summary: The study found that the walking intervention improved chronic pain-related physical functioning, as measured by the Roland and Morris Disability Questionnaire, and also examined its effects on pain intensity, emotional functioning, and overall improvement. Secondary outcomes included potential reductions in healthcare utilization and opioid use.
population_specificity: African American patients with chronic hip, back, or knee pain.
effective_dosage: 6 telephone counseling sessions over 8-10 weeks, with pedometer use.
study_duration: 8-10 weeks (intervention), with follow-up assessments at 3 and 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the long-term patterns, determinants, and effects of exercise interventions, including walking, on physical activity behavior in breast cancer survivors.
results_summary: Walking was maintained over time among breast cancer survivors, unlike cycling, which saw a decline. The exercise intervention helped sustain physical activity during therapy but did not prevent long-term inactivity in many survivors.
population_specificity: Breast cancer survivors undergoing adjuvant chemo- or radiotherapy.
study_duration: Assessed before, during, and up to 12 months post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of traditional and CAD/CAM prosthetic sockets on clinical characteristics and quality of life in patients with transtibial amputation.
results_summary: CAD/CAM prosthetic sockets significantly improved walking time, distance, pain-free walking time, prosthesis application time, and adaptation time compared to traditional sockets. Quality of life measures, except emotional role limitation, were also significantly better with CAD/CAM sockets.
population_specificity: 72 patients with transtibial amputation (36 using CAD/CAM sockets, 36 using traditional sockets).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of abobotulinumtoxinA + standard of care versus placebo + standard of care in helping children with cerebral palsy achieve functional gait improvement goals.
results_summary: Both doses of abobotulinumtoxinA (10 and 15 U/kg/leg) significantly improved Goal Attainment Scaling T scores compared to placebo at weeks 4 and 12, with notable improvements in walking pattern, falling, tripping, and endurance.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients with dynamic equinus due to cerebral palsy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of a web-based lifestyle intervention, including walking, on physical activity, dietary intake, and quality of life in individuals with metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant increases in walking activity (505.2±505.3 MET-min/week) compared to the control group (321±884 MET-min/week), indicating improved physical activity levels. The study also noted improvements in general health and vitality related to quality of life.
population_specificity: Adults with metabolic syndrome in Tehran, Iran.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the accuracy and feasibility of different physical activity assessment tools (pedometer, IPAQ, and ActiGraph) for measuring walking and other physical activity dimensions in patients with Bronchiectasis.
results_summary: The study found that ActiGraph and pedometer showed very good agreement for step counts (97%), but ActiGraph provided more precise measurements of physical activity intensity and time spent walking. IPAQ was less accurate, overestimating moderate-vigorous physical activity and underestimating sedentary time compared to ActiGraph.
population_specificity: Patients with Bronchiectasis (55 participants, 22 male).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (assessment tools, not an intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of a supervised community-based exercise program on balance, balance confidence, and gait in individuals with lower limb amputation.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements across six clinical outcome measures, with moderate effect sizes for balance and walking ability. Participants experienced clinically meaningful improvements in balance, balance confidence, and walking ability.
population_specificity: Individuals with lower limb amputation (mean age: 50.8 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the participation, fidelity, satisfaction, and reasons for completion/non-completion of the VPAN program, which included walking groups as a strategy to improve physical activity and nutrition in adults with Metabolic Syndrome.
results_summary: Most participants found the program resources and strategies useful, reporting increased physical activity and improved diet. Education sessions were the most preferred strategy, with high attendance, while work commitments and busy schedules were the main reasons for withdrawal.
population_specificity: Adults aged 50-65 years with Metabolic Syndrome in Vietnam.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether financial incentives, donations to charity, or a combination of both could increase older adults' initial uptake and retention of increased walking levels.
results_summary: All intervention groups showed higher adherence to walking goals during the 16-week intervention compared to controls, but no significant difference was observed during the 4-week follow-up period.
population_specificity: Ninety-four adults aged ≥65 years from Philadelphia-area retirement communities.
effective_dosage: Participants aimed for a 50% increase in daily steps, monitored via digital pedometers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether a physical activity program, including walking, combined with nutritional assessment, could prevent frailty progression in pre-frail older adults.
results_summary: The intervention group showed a lower progression to frailty (4.9% vs. 15.3% in controls) and increased outdoor walking hours (0.97 vs. 0.73 hours/day), but no significant improvements in muscle strength or gait speed were observed.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling pre-frail older adults (≥70 years) consulting in primary care.
effective_dosage: Not specified (physical activity program included aerobic exercise and mixed strengthening, balance, and coordination exercises).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether implicit descriptive social norms (e.g., photos and text of active peers) could influence behavioral intention and participation in organized physical activity (e.g., walking) among inactive older adults in residential care.
results_summary: The study found that exposure to implicit descriptive norms of active peers was associated with increased implicit intention to participate in physical activity and higher self-reported participation (80% vs. 22% in the control group) at 3-month follow-up. No significant effects were observed on explicit intention.
population_specificity: Older adults (mean age 87, range 80-95) living in a residential care setting, 53% male.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the relationship between walking and sundown syndrome in people with Alzheimer disease, and assess how walking duration and accompanying walker influenced sleep quality and sundown syndrome.
results_summary: The study found that sundown syndrome was significantly correlated with sleep quality, and that advanced dementia, poor sleep quality, and shorter weekly walking duration were influencing factors. Walking with relatives and longer walking time improved sleep quality and alleviated sundown syndrome.
population_specificity: People with Alzheimer disease living in the community in southern Taiwan.
effective_dosage: Weekly duration of walking (specific hours not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of robotic-assisted gait training (RAGT) for children with gait disorders, focusing on modes of delivery and potential benefits.
results_summary: Most individual trials reported some positive benefits for RAGT in children with cerebral palsy, such as improved standing ability, walking speed, and distance, but a meta-analysis of two RCTs did not confirm these findings. The evidence was weak and inconsistent, with highly variable training schedules and minimal reported adverse events.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with altered gait, primarily those with cerebral palsy.
effective_dosage: Training schedules were highly variable in duration and frequency (not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the prevalence of depression in peripheral arterial disease patients, its independent association with the disease, and factors that could be targeted for intervention.
results_summary: Depression prevalence in peripheral arterial disease patients ranged from 3-48%, comparable to coronary artery disease rates. Depression negatively influenced walking ability and physical function independently of peripheral arterial disease.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral arterial disease, particularly those who were female, African American, and had severe symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of twelve weeks of physical-cognitive training on executive cognitive function and gait performance in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that integrating cognitive demands into physical training improved executive cognitive function and gait performance in older adults. The results suggest that combined physical-cognitive training may counteract age-related decline in physical and mental function.
population_specificity: Healthy, active older adults aged 72.30 ± 5.84 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the neurohumoral and endothelial responses to blood pressure-lowering effects of heated water-based exercise, including walking, in patients with resistant hypertension.
results_summary: The study found that heated water-based exercise, including walking, significantly lowered blood pressure in resistant hypertension patients and reduced neurohumoral activation. The intervention group showed improvements in clinic and 24-hour BP measurements compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 44 patients with true resistant hypertension (mean age 53.3±0.9 years).
effective_dosage: 1-hour sessions of callisthenic exercises and walking in a heated pool, three times weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a pedometer-based walking intervention, delivered either by post or with nurse support, in increasing physical activity levels among predominantly inactive adults.
results_summary: The study found that both postal and nurse-supported pedometer interventions significantly increased daily step counts (by ~10%) and time in moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (by ~33%) compared to usual care, with no significant difference between the two intervention methods.
population_specificity: Predominantly inactive adults aged 45-75 years without physical activity contraindications.
effective_dosage: Pedometer use with a 12-week walking program and physical activity diaries; nurse group also received three physical activity consultations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the validity of sit-to-stand tests (STSs) in people with multiple sclerosis (PwMS) and their ability to predict falls and detect changes in balance and mobility.
results_summary: The study found that the 5 and 10 STSs were valid for assessing mobility in PwMS but did not effectively identify fallers or detect changes in balance. Correlations were strong with other mobility tests but not with falls or near-fall incidents.
population_specificity: People with multiple sclerosis (PwMS) with limited but retained walking ability (Expanded Disability Status Scale score ≤6.0).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study focused on tests, not a walking intervention).
study_duration: 7-week intervention with a 14-week follow-up for fall reporting.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of gait training with body weight support on a treadmill versus overground in individuals with chronic stroke.
results_summary: Both treadmill and overground training improved gait speed, endurance, functional independence, and lower limb recovery, but only the overground group improved step length symmetry ratio. Improvements were sustained at 6 weeks post-intervention.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic stroke (>6 months post-stroke).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of lower extremity power training and detraining on gait mechanics and velocity in healthy older adults.
results_summary: Power training increased fast gait velocity by 5.9%, with improvements linked to increased hip muscle function. Detraining further improved gait velocity (4.7%) while shifting reliance from hip to knee and ankle muscle function.
population_specificity: Healthy older adults (control group: 69.1±4.4 years, n=14; training group: 72.9±5.4 years, n=15).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify risk factors, including pre-operative walking disability, associated with venous thromboembolism (VTE) after spine surgery.
results_summary: The study found that pre-operative walking disability significantly increased the risk of VTE (OR = 4.80, P < 0.00001), indicating a strong association between mobility impairment and post-surgical complications.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing spine surgery for degenerative diseases (34,597 patients, including 624 with VTE).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how walking speed affects foot kinematics in the frontal plane and whether this relationship changes with medially inclined insoles that increase pronation.
results_summary: Faster walking speeds increased foot eversion under normal conditions, but this effect reversed with medially inclined insoles, suggesting greater active control of foot motion to improve push-off efficiency. The study found no main effect of speed on average calcaneal position but noted a significant interaction between insole type and walking speed.
population_specificity: 26 healthy young adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the correlations between JOA scores and gait parameters in patients with cervical spondylotic myelopathy (CSM) and lumbar intervertebral disc herniation (LDH).
results_summary: The study found a significant correlation between JOA lumbar scores and gait speed in LDH patients, suggesting the JOA lumbar scoring system reflects gait impairment. However, the JOA cervical scoring system may need improvement for evaluating walking ability in CSM patients.
population_specificity: 32 CSM and 30 LDH patients with gait dysfunction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 7-day intensive preoperative pulmonary rehabilitation (PR) program, including inspiratory muscle training (IMT) and aerobic endurance training, improved physical and psychological outcomes in elderly lung cancer patients scheduled for lobectomy.
results_summary: The study found that the PR group showed significant improvements in 6-minute walking distance (6-MWD) and peak expiratory flow (PEF) compared to the control group. Additionally, the PR group had shorter postoperative and total hospital stays and a lower incidence of postoperative pulmonary complications (PPCs).
population_specificity: Elderly patients (aged ≥70 years) with lung cancer scheduled for lobectomy.
effective_dosage: Systematic and highly intensive preoperative PR training for 1 week (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of adaptability treadmill training, conventional treadmill training, and usual physical therapy in improving walking ability and reducing fear of falling and fall incidence in older adults rehabilitating from a fall-related hip fracture.
results_summary: All three interventions (adaptability treadmill training, conventional treadmill training, and usual physical therapy) resulted in similar improvements in walking ability, fear of falling, and fall incidence. However, adaptability treadmill training showed superiority in dual-task walking speed, while conventional treadmill training was better for the Functional Ambulation Category.
population_specificity: Older adults (mean age 83.3 ± 6.7 years) rehabilitating from a fall-related hip fracture.

study_goal: The study does not focus on Walking; it examines the clinical management of metastatic melanoma and associated complications.
results_summary: The study does not report findings related to Walking; it describes a patient's progression of metastatic melanoma and treatment with immunotherapy.
population_specificity: A 60-year-old former smoker with metastatic melanoma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of diet and exercise interventions, including walking, on lean mass and functional outcomes in older adults with sarcopenia or frailty.
results_summary: Exercise interventions, including walking, improved lower body muscle strength but had inconsistent effects on walking speed and grip strength. Combined diet and exercise interventions showed more consistent benefits.
population_specificity: Older adults with sarcopenia or frailty.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the significance of backward walking as a form of interval march training for patients after abdominal aortic aneurysm surgery compared to forward walking and routine physiotherapy.
results_summary: Backward walking resulted in a statistically significant lower reduction of walking distance compared to the control group. Both backward and forward walking groups showed better mean speed post-operation than the control group, with no significant differences between the experimental groups in walking speed or heart rate.
population_specificity: Males aged 65-75 years with stable cardiologic status, absence of neurological disorders, and non-symptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine how endpoints like 6-minute walking distance (6MWD) and functional class changes are associated with outcomes in patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) and chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (CTEPH).
results_summary: The study found that reductions in 6MWD, deterioration in WHO functional class, and delays in clinical worsening are meaningful endpoints associated with patient outcomes in PAH and CTEPH. These endpoints help compare interventions and therapies, with hospitalization being a key cost-related factor.
population_specificity: Patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) and chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (CTEPH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the characteristics and prognosis of interstitial lung disease (ILD) associated with pulmonary hypertension (PH), focusing on exercise capacity (measured by 6-minute walking distance) and hemodynamic parameters.
results_summary: The study found that ILD patients with PH had severely impaired exercise capacity (335.0 ± 190.9 m in the 6-minute walking test) and cardiac function compared to ILD patients without PH. Pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR) was the only significant prognostic factor associated with death in this group.
population_specificity: Predominantly Chinese patients with ILD-associated PH confirmed by right heart catheterization (mean age 60.0 ± 12.2 years).
study_duration: Not specified (observational study with follow-up survival rates at 1, 3, and 5 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and efficacy of SpinalonTM (a combination of buspirone, levodopa, and carbidopa) in restoring locomotor capabilities in patients with motor-complete spinal cord injury (SCI).
results_summary: SpinalonTM showed no significant safety concerns at lower doses, with only mild nausea reported. Higher doses reached maximum tolerated dose due to adverse events like vomiting. EMG activity with locomotor-like characteristics was observed only in SpinalonTM-treated groups.
population_specificity: 45 subjects with SCI classified as complete (AIS A) or motor-complete/sensory incomplete (AIS B) for at least 3 months.
effective_dosage: 10-35 mg buspirone/100-350 mg levodopa/25-85 mg carbidopa (lower doses); 50 mg/500 mg/125 mg (higher doses).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of a 12-week walking program on knee pain in patients with severe knee osteoarthritis, as well as its secondary effects on cardiovascular health, function, and quality of life.
results_summary: The walking program did not reduce knee pain but showed cardiovascular benefits, including improved systolic blood pressure and walking speed. Adherent participants also had more daily steps, increased walking time, reduced waist circumference, but reported increased knee stiffness.
population_specificity: Patients with severe knee osteoarthritis and increased cardiovascular risk.
effective_dosage: 70 minutes per week of at least moderate intensity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether preoperative physical activity interventions (PAIs) involving walking could increase and maintain post-operative physical activity levels in bariatric surgery patients.
results_summary: The study found that participants in the PAI group showed significantly greater increases in moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (MVPA) and steps per day compared to the standard care group, with these improvements maintained post-operatively. The effects were statistically significant at post-intervention and follow-up for steps, but only at post-intervention for MVPA.
population_specificity: Bariatric surgery patients (n=36, with 22 in PAI and 14 in standard care).
effective_dosage: Weekly counseling to increase walking exercise (specific step count or duration not detailed).
study_duration: 6 weeks of preoperative intervention, with follow-up at 6 months post-operatively.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the experiences of adults with intellectual disabilities participating in a walking programme (Walk Well) and assess its impact on physical activity.
results_summary: Participants reported positive experiences with the programme, though not all showed significant increases in walking. Barriers included difficulties with self-monitoring and reliance on carers for support.
population_specificity: Adults with intellectual disabilities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether intensive physical therapy (PT) initiated within the first 2 weeks after a stroke could improve motor control recovery.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in motor control improvement between intensive PT and standard PT, as measured by the Fugl-Meyer score. Secondary outcomes, including walking ability, balance, and autonomy, also showed no significant benefits from intensive PT.
population_specificity: Patients within 72 hours of their first hemispheric stroke, predominantly severe cases (NIHSS score ≥8 for 82%).
effective_dosage: Intensive PT included 45 minutes of additional exercises per day compared to standard PT (20 minutes/day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess acute responses to passive heat via lower-limb, hot-water immersion in patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD) and healthy elderly controls.
results_summary: The study found that hot-water immersion increased shear rate and improved lower-limb perfusion, suggesting potential cardiovascular benefits for both PAD patients and healthy elderly individuals.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD) and healthy elderly controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if caregiver-mediated exercises (CME) improve functional ability and health-related quality of life in people with stroke and assess the effect on caregiver burden.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of CME on basic or extended activities of daily living (ADL) but noted improvements in standing balance, quality of life, and Six-Minute Walking Test distance. Caregiver burden did not increase with CME.
population_specificity: Adults with stroke and their caregivers.
study_duration: Varies by study (not specified in abstract)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of tricuspid regurgitation (TR) severity on functional outcomes, including 6-minute walking distance, in patients undergoing MitraClip procedures for mitral regurgitation.
results_summary: The study found that 6-minute walking distance significantly improved in patients with TR ≤ II but not in those with TR > II, indicating that baseline TR severity influences functional outcomes post-MitraClip. Higher TR grades were also associated with increased mortality and worse NT-pro-BNP levels.
population_specificity: 261 patients (mean age 76.6 ± 10) with symptomatic mitral regurgitation, primarily functional MR (75.2%), undergoing MitraClip procedures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and cost-effectiveness of supervised exercise therapy (SET) for improving walking distance and health-related quality of life in patients with intermittent claudication (IC).
results_summary: SET was found to robustly alleviate claudication symptoms, improve walking distance, and enhance health-related quality of life, making it the most cost-effective treatment for IC. However, global implementation of SET is limited by barriers such as lack of specialized networks, physician awareness, and financial incentives.
population_specificity: Older patients with intermittent claudication (IC), often multimorbid and with atherosclerotic disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if snacking could prevent exercise-induced reductions in plasma glucose (PG) and limit post-exercise PG elevations in individuals with type 1 diabetes using closed-loop insulin delivery during brisk walking.
results_summary: Snacking during exercise prevented significant drops in PG (10 ± 13 mg/dL increase vs. 53 ± 10 mg/dL decrease without snacking) and eliminated hypoglycemia requiring rescue treatment. Insulin delivery was higher with snacking (1.8 ± 0.4 U vs. 0.7 ± 0.1 U).
population_specificity: 12 individuals with type 1 diabetes, aged 13-36 years.
effective_dosage: Not specified (snacking strategy details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of exercise therapy, including walking, on fatigue and other symptoms in patients with chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS) compared to other interventions or controls.
results_summary: Exercise therapy, including walking, reduced fatigue and improved sleep, physical functioning, and self-perceived health in CFS patients, with no evidence of worsening outcomes. Its effectiveness was similar to cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) and greater than pacing.
population_specificity: Adults with a primary diagnosis of chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS).
effective_dosage: Mixed intensity aerobic exercise (e.g., walking, swimming, cycling) for 12 to 26 weeks; exact walking dosage not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare functional independence changes after neurorehabilitation between patients with nontraumatic subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) and those with intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) or acute ischemic stroke (AIS).
results_summary: Patients with nontraumatic SAH showed greater progress in functional independence during neurorehabilitation compared to ICH/AIS patients, particularly in specific FIM items like stair walking, but were discharged with lower overall functional levels. Both groups significantly improved their functional outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with first-time nontraumatic SAH (n=212) and age-matched patients with first-time ICH/AIS (n=448).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review best practices for endoscopic lung volume reduction (ELVR) using Zephyr valves in patients with severe emphysema.
results_summary: The study found that ELVR with Zephyr valves improves pulmonary function, exercise capacity, and quality of life in selected emphysema patients without collateral ventilation. Complications like pneumothorax were noted but manageable.
population_specificity: Patients with severe emphysema (residual volume >175% predicted, FEV1 <50% predicted, 6-min walking distance >100 m) and no collateral ventilation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding statins to standard treatment improves outcomes, including 6-minute walking distance, in adult patients with pulmonary hypertension.
results_summary: The study found that statins did not significantly improve 6-minute walking distance, reduce dyspnea scores, lower clinical worsening risk, or decrease systolic pulmonary arterial pressure in PH patients. Subgroup analysis for PH due to COPD or non-COPD also showed no significant benefits.
population_specificity: Adult patients with pulmonary hypertension (PH), including subgroups with PH due to COPD and non-COPD causes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if biofeedback during lower limb activities (including walking) is more effective than usual therapy in improving those activities post-stroke and whether benefits are maintained beyond the intervention.
results_summary: Biofeedback improved performance of lower limb activities more than usual therapy, with a standardized mean difference of 0.50 (95% CI 0.30 to 0.70). The study concluded that biofeedback is more effective but noted the need for further research on long-term effects.
population_specificity: People who have had a stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review studies measuring gait parameters and energy consumption in adolescents with idiopathic scoliosis (AIS) during walking without intervention.
results_summary: Most studies found no significant differences in walking speed, cadence, or step width between AIS patients and normal participants, but patients showed reduced hip/pelvic motion, higher energy cost, stepping asymmetry, and ground reaction force asymmetry.
population_specificity: Adolescents with idiopathic scoliosis (AIS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the short-term effects of rectus femoris neurotomy for treating spastic stiff-knee gait in patients with hemiparesis.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in maximal walking distance, gait speed, stride length, and kinematic parameters after rectus femoris neurotomy. Rectus femoris muscle activity during gait normalized, and early swing phase knee extension moment decreased.
population_specificity: Seven ambulatory patients with hemiparesis of spinal or cerebral origin and spastic stiff-knee gait.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combined strength and endurance exercise training improves functional performance, including walking ability, in individuals with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The exercise group showed significant improvements in walking ability (6-minute walk, 10-m walk), functional lower limb strength (30-second sit-to-stand), and balance (Functional Reach Test) compared to baseline and the control group.
population_specificity: Fifteen participants with spastic cerebral palsy.
effective_dosage: 70 minutes per day, 3 days per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the short-term effects of virtual walking integrated physiotherapy on pain, function, and kinesiophobia in patients with subacute and chronic non-specific low-back pain.
results_summary: Both groups improved, but the virtual walking group showed significantly better outcomes in pain (VAS), kinesiophobia (TKS), mobility (TUG), and endurance (6MWT). Virtual walking integrated physiotherapy was more effective than traditional physiotherapy for these parameters.
population_specificity: Patients with subacute and chronic non-specific low-back pain (44 participants, 22 per group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize the research literature on test protocols and measurement properties of time-limited walk tests in people poststroke.
results_summary: The study found strong evidence of the reliability and construct validity of the 6-minute walk test (6MWT) poststroke, with moderate-to-strong correlations between 6MWT distance and various functional measures. Protocol variations, such as walkway length and walking aid, influenced performance, highlighting the need for standardized protocols.
population_specificity: People poststroke (acute phase <1 month and beyond).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (walk tests, not a supplement).
study_duration: Not specified (systematic review of existing studies).

study_goal: To determine the effectiveness of technology-based distance physical rehabilitation interventions in multiple sclerosis (MS) on physical activity and walking.
results_summary: Technology-based distance physical rehabilitation had a large effect on physical activity but no significant differences were observed in walking outcomes. Further research is needed to assess the impact on walking in MS.
population_specificity: Persons with multiple sclerosis (MS)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the safety and effectiveness of exercise, including walking, for improving joint function and recovery in people with haemophilia.
results_summary: Treadmill walking improved balance in children and increased peak torque of knee flexors and extensors when combined with other exercises. Partial weight-bearing exercises, including walking, improved walking tolerance and muscle strength compared to static exercises.
population_specificity: Males aged 8 to 49 years with haemophilia A or B of any severity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the clinical utility of the 6-minute walk test (6MWT) for assessing walking capacity in patients with moderate Parkinson's disease (PD).
results_summary: The study found that the 6MWT was significantly correlated with the Timed 'Up & Go' test (TUG) and energy cost of walking (Ec), confirming its convergent validity and clinical utility for moderate PD patients. Multiple regression analysis showed TUG and Ec independently correlated with 6MWT results, while age, HY stage, and cadence were not.
population_specificity: 24 patients with moderate Parkinson's disease (average Hoehn and Yahr stage 3.1±0.5).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of early physical activity time (EPAT) on pain, recovery of daily living abilities, and vertebral collapse progression in patients with acute vertebral compression fractures (VCFs).
results_summary: EPAT was associated with better recovery of daily living abilities (mFIM scores) but showed no significant effect on pain reduction (VRS scores) or vertebral collapse progression. The active group had better functional gains compared to the sedentary group.
population_specificity: 69 patients with acute VCFs treated conservatively at Nagasaki Memorial Hospital.
effective_dosage: Activity time corresponding to 1.8-8.3 metabolic equivalent activities during the first week after admission.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of HYADD4-G, a hyaluronic acid-based hydrogel, on improving pain and function in professional soccer players with knee chondropathy.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in KOOS and VAS scores at 1, 3, and 6 months post-treatment, indicating reduced pain and enhanced joint function. Statistical analysis confirmed these improvements were significant (P<0.05).
population_specificity: Thirty male professional soccer players in the Italian League (2014-2015) with traumatic or degenerative knee chondropathy.
effective_dosage: 3 mL of 8 mg/mL HYADD4-G, administered twice at a one-week interval.

study_goal: To examine the effects of brisk walking combined with music in the evening on sleep quality in sedentary older adults with chronic insomnia.
results_summary: Brisk walking combined with music improved subjective sleep quality in adults with insomnia, though listening to soothing music before bedtime was more effective at reducing wake time after sleep onset compared to brisk walking.
population_specificity: Sedentary older adults (aged 50-75) with chronic insomnia in Taiwan.
study_duration: Each intervention lasted 30 minutes, with two sessions separated by 1 week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the electromyographic cost, coactivation, and cost of transport during walking in chronic heart failure and heart transplant patients compared to healthy controls.
results_summary: The study found that chronic heart failure and heart transplant patients had higher electromyographic cost, leg coactivation, and cost of transport during walking compared to controls. The minimum electromyographic cost occurred at speeds higher than the self-selected walking speed in patients, unlike controls.
population_specificity: Twelve chronic heart failure patients, twelve healthy controls, and five heart transplant patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and acceptability of a coaching intervention (Walk This Way) to reduce sedentary behavior and increase physical activity in people with serious mental illness (SMI).
results_summary: The study found that the Walk This Way intervention was feasible and acceptable, with secondary aims suggesting potential reductions in sedentary behavior and increases in activity levels, though specific efficacy results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: People with serious mental illness (psychosis, bipolar disorder, and major depressive disorder) who were overweight, at risk for or had diabetes, smoked tobacco, or had a sedentary lifestyle.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention included setting daily walking targets and weekly walking groups).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a targeted physiotherapy intervention (PUSH) was more effective than a non-specific intervention (PULSE) in restoring independent community ambulation in older adults after hip fracture.
results_summary: The study compared PUSH (aerobic conditioning, specificity of training, muscle overload) and PULSE (flexibility, range of motion exercises) in improving walking ability. Primary outcomes focused on the ability to walk 300+ meters in 6 minutes at 16 weeks, with additional measures including endurance, balance, and function.
population_specificity: Older adults (≥60 years) recovering from hip fractures, previously community-dwelling and ambulatory without assistance.
effective_dosage: 32 physiotherapy visits (2 per week for 16 weeks), plus dietary counseling and supplements (vitamin D, calcium, multivitamins).
study_duration: 16 weeks (with follow-up at 40 weeks for a subset).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of individual shear rate therapy (ISRT) on nitric oxide levels in blood plasma and related molecular markers in peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) in healthy subjects and PAD patients.
results_summary: Short-term ISRT reduced NOS2 expression in PBMCs, while long-term ISRT increased plasma nitrite levels in PAD patients, suggesting a vascular-stimulating effect comparable to physical exercise.
population_specificity: 26 healthy subjects and 14 PAD patients with stable intermittent claudication.
effective_dosage: One session of treadmill training and one session of ISRT (short-term); 30 hours of long-term ISRT (specific frequency not detailed).
study_duration: Short-term: single sessions; long-term: 30 hours total.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare bone microarchitecture, physical function, and fracture risk factors in elderly women with Type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) versus nondiabetic controls.
results_summary: Women with T2DM had more favorable bone microarchitecture but reduced bone material strength and impaired physical function (e.g., slower walking speed, worse balance) compared to controls, potentially explaining their higher fracture risk.
population_specificity: Women aged 75–80 years in Gothenburg, Sweden (99 with T2DM, 954 controls).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of short-term interval walking training (IWT) and continuous walking training (CWT) on glycaemic control and oxidative stress levels in individuals with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: IWT significantly reduced maximum glucose levels and glycaemic variability (MAGE), while CWT showed no significant changes. Neither intervention affected systemic oxidative stress levels or physical fitness.
population_specificity: Individuals with type 2 diabetes (n=14).
effective_dosage: Ten supervised treadmill sessions, 60 minutes per session (IWT: alternating 3 min at slow [58.9% peak oxygen consumption] and fast [90.0% peak oxygen consumption] walking speeds; CWT: moderate speed [75.6% peak oxygen consumption]).
study_duration: 2 weeks per intervention, with 4-8 week washout periods.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether staff-directed facilitation of early mobilization (walking) in an Enhanced Recovery Program (ERP) improves recovery outcomes after colorectal surgery compared to usual care.
results_summary: The study found that facilitated mobilization increased adherence to walking targets and step counts during the early postoperative days but did not improve recovery of walking capacity at 4 weeks or other outcomes. The intervention showed no significant long-term benefits despite short-term improvements in mobilization.
population_specificity: 99 colorectal surgery patients (median age 63, 57% male, 80% laparoscopic) in an established ERP.
effective_dosage: Staff-assisted transfers and walking from postoperative days 0-3.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of interrupting prolonged sitting with brief bouts of walking or resistance activities on 22-hour glucose homeostasis in adults with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Both light-intensity walking (LW) and simple resistance activities (SRA) significantly reduced 22-hour glucose and nocturnal mean glucose concentrations compared to prolonged sitting, with improvements sustained until the following morning.
population_specificity: Inactive overweight/obese adults with type 2 diabetes (14 men; 62 ± 6 years).
effective_dosage: 3-minute bouts of light-intensity walking at 3.2 km/h every 30 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether treadmill training with visual biofeedback improves gait symmetry and spatiotemporal/kinematic parameters in chronic stroke patients.
results_summary: Treadmill training improved gait symmetry (step length, stance phase time, inter-limb ratio) in the intervention group, with effects maintained at 6 months. No significant difference was found between the biofeedback and control groups.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke patients (n=30).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the biomechanical outcomes of using prosthetic knees and ankles with damping mechanisms compared to non-damped prostheses in individuals with lower limb amputation.
results_summary: The review found heterogeneous methodologies and inconsistent findings across studies, with only self-selected gait speed showing a consistent difference when dampers were applied. Further research is needed to clarify the benefits of damped prosthetic components.
population_specificity: Individuals with lower limb amputation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether prebiotic-rich yogurt could improve metabolic indices and reduce menopausal symptoms in menopausal women compared to regular yogurt.
results_summary: The study found that prebiotic-rich yogurt significantly reduced menopausal symptoms (including anxiety, depression, and vasomotor symptoms) and lowered low-density lipoprotein levels, though it increased serum insulin levels compared to regular yogurt.
population_specificity: 60 menopausal women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of yogurt (YG) on the gut microbiota and diarrhea symptoms in mice with antibiotic-associated diarrhea (AAD).
results_summary: Yogurt significantly reduced diarrhea scores, inhibited increases in cecum index and cecal length, and altered gut microbiota composition by increasing Firmicutes and decreasing Bacteroidetes and Bacteroidaceae. YG also reduced the abundance of Bacteroides or Parasutterella at the genus level.
population_specificity: Mice with antibiotic-associated diarrhea (AAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of probiotic yogurt versus ordinary yogurt on inflammatory, endothelial, lipid, and renal indices in patients with chronic heart failure (CHF).
results_summary: Probiotic yogurt significantly increased sTWEAK levels compared to ordinary yogurt, suggesting potential anti-inflammatory benefits in CHF patients. No significant differences were observed for other measured indices.
population_specificity: 90 patients with chronic heart failure (CHF), 78 of whom completed the study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of low-fat yogurt fortified with nano-encapsulated vitamin D3 in reducing systemic inflammation in individuals with abdominal obesity.
results_summary: Fortified yogurt significantly reduced serum levels of neutrophils, lymphocytes, platelets, and RDW, as well as inflammatory ratios (NLR, PLR, RPR), indicating decreased inflammation in participants.
population_specificity: Abdominally obese participants
effective_dosage: 150 g/day of low-fat yogurt fortified with 1500 IU nano-encapsulated vitamin D3

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of probiotic yogurt consumption on liver enzymes, steatosis, and liver fibrosis in patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
results_summary: The study did not report specific results but proposed to evaluate biochemical indicators, insulin resistance, steatosis, and fibrosis before and after 12 weeks of probiotic yogurt consumption compared to plain yogurt.
population_specificity: Sixty-eight patients with NAFLD, block-matched for sex, BMI, and age.
effective_dosage: 300 g/d probiotic yogurt containing 10^6 cfu/g of Lactobacillus acidophilus and Bifidobacterium lactis strains.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the antibacterial and antibiofilm activity of a novel bacteriocin (LSX01) from Lactobacillus paracasei LS-6 against Staphylococcus aureus in dairy products.
results_summary: The study found that LSX01 exhibited strong antibacterial and antibiofilm effects against S. aureus, with a low minimum inhibitory concentration (16.90 μg/mL), broad-spectrum antimicrobial activity, and tolerance to heat and acid-base treatments. It also disrupted S. aureus cell membranes and inhibited biofilm formation.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on bacterial strains).
effective_dosage: Minimum inhibitory concentration of 16.90 μg/mL against S. aureus_45.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of sugar replacements (stevia, sucralose, and sorbitol) on the physicochemical, microbiological, microstructural, and sensory characteristics of probiotic-frozen yogurt.
results_summary: The study found that sugar replacements (stevia, sucralose, and sorbitol) maintained probiotic viability (>6.00 log10 CFU g−1) for up to 60 days and improved overrun, hardness, and viscosity compared to sucrose. Sensory acceptability was highest in treatments with sweeteners (F3, F4, F2).
population_specificity: Consumers seeking sugar-free probiotic-frozen yogurt, particularly those with lactose intolerance or metabolic syndrome.
effective_dosage: Not specified (four treatments with varying sweeteners).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a synbiotic yogurt (containing inulin and Lactobacillus rhamnosus GG) enhances calcium absorption compared to a control yogurt in young adult women.
results_summary: The synbiotic yogurt showed a trend toward higher calcium absorption (1.24 ratio in 0-36-h urine pool) compared to the control yogurt, with about two-thirds of participants responding positively. Responders had higher vegetable intake and tended to have higher potassium and calcium intakes.
population_specificity: Normal-weight young adult women (25.0 ± 3.5 years, n = 30).
effective_dosage: 185 mL daily, containing 4 g inulin and >1 × 10^7 CFU/mL Lactobacillus rhamnosus GG.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-diabetic effects of yak yogurt-derived Lactobacillus plantarum SHY130 and its potential mechanisms in high-fat diet and streptozotocin-induced diabetic mice.
results_summary: L. plantarum SHY130 improved blood glucose regulation, reduced insulin resistance, preserved pancreatic β-cell mass, increased SCFA receptor expression, and modulated gut microbiota to enhance SCFA-producing bacteria in diabetic mice.
population_specificity: C57BL/6J mice with high-fat diet and streptozotocin-induced type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether vitamin D-supplemented yogurt could reduce Candida infections in critically ill children on broad-spectrum antibiotics.
results_summary: The study found that vitamin D-supplemented yogurt significantly reduced candiduria and candidaemia cases compared to plain yogurt, and shortened PICU stays, though mortality rates were similar between groups.
population_specificity: Children aged 12 months to 5 years admitted to a pediatric intensive care unit (PICU) on broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy.
effective_dosage: 300 IU/day of vitamin D in yogurt.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of non-fat, conventional yogurt consumption on appetite hormone responses in overweight patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) following a non-energy-restricted diet.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in glucose, insulin, ghrelin, GLP-1, PYY responses, or subjective appetite ratings after 12 weeks of yogurt consumption. Regular consumption of non-fat yogurt did not affect appetite hormone responses in the studied population.
population_specificity: Overweight patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of higher-pressure homogenization and extended shelf life (ESL) processing on the curd structure and texture of set yogurt.
results_summary: The study found that smaller fat globule sizes (<0.6 µm) achieved via high-pressure homogenization (35 MPa + 5 MPa) improved curd hardness and firmness in ESL-processed yogurt, making it suitable for commercial transport while maintaining smooth texture. Sensory evaluation scores were significantly favorable for yogurt produced with this method.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study on yogurt samples)
effective_dosage: Not applicable (processing conditions: 35 MPa first stage, 5 MPa second stage homogenization; heat treatments varied)
study_duration: Not specified (fermentation and evaluation timeframe not detailed)

study_goal: The study aimed to investigate the mechanism of action of GFAP in tic disorder and its potential influence on neuroprotection and behavior improvement.
results_summary: The study found that GFAP intervention reduced the frequency and intensity of convulsions, suggesting a neuroprotective effect, possibly through modulation of inflammatory signaling pathways like NF-κB.
population_specificity: Not specified (animal or human study not clearly stated in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and efficacy of a Hoodia gordonii purified extract (HgPE) formulated in a yogurt drink for weight management in overweight women.
results_summary: The study found that HgPE in yogurt was less well tolerated than placebo, causing nausea, vomiting, and skin sensation disturbances, with no significant effects on energy intake or body weight. Adverse changes in vital signs and lab parameters were observed in the HgPE group.
population_specificity: Healthy, overweight women stratified by percentage body fat.
effective_dosage: 1110 mg HgPE twice daily (before breakfast and dinner).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of probiotic goat yogurt supplemented with Bifidobacterium longum in treating pediatric functional chronic intestinal constipation (FCIC).
results_summary: Both probiotic and non-supplemented yogurt improved defecation frequency and pain, but the probiotic group showed significantly greater improvements in stool consistency, defecation pain, and abdominal pain. The benefits of probiotic supplementation were more pronounced in the first phase of the study.
population_specificity: 59 students aged 5-15 years with FCIC, diagnosed using Roma III criteria.
effective_dosage: 10^9 colony-forming units/mL of Bifidobacterium longum daily.
study_duration: 5 weeks per treatment phase, with a crossover after the first phase (total 10 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of Bifidobacterium animalis ssp. lactis Bf-6-supplemented yogurt on colonic transit time in women with a history of straining during bowel movements or hard stools.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in colonic transit time between the active and control periods in the cross-over trial, but analysis of period 1 alone showed a significant reduction in transit time with the active yogurt (35.2 h vs. 52.9 h). Few adverse events were reported, with no differences between groups.
population_specificity: Sixty-eight generally healthy women with a self-reported history of straining during bowel movements or hard/lumpy stools in the past 2 years.
study_duration: 14 days per treatment period, with a 6-week washout between treatments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review Yohimbine's therapeutic potential, safety profile, and strategies to enhance bioavailability while reducing toxicity.
results_summary: Yohimbine shows promise for treating erectile dysfunction and metabolic disorders but has toxicological concerns at higher doses. Ongoing research is needed to fully assess its efficacy and safety.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of existing research).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate Yohimbine's anti-inflammatory, anti-oxidant, and anti-fibrotic effects in LPS/TGF-β-induced cell differentiation and bleomycin-induced pulmonary fibrosis in rats.
results_summary: Yohimbine significantly reduced inflammatory, oxidative stress, and fibrotic markers in both cell and rat models, improved lung architecture, and restored lung function dose-dependently by regulating the MAPK pathway.
population_specificity: BEAS-2B/LL29 cells and bleomycin-induced pulmonary fibrosis model in rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the pharmacokinetic interactions between clomipramine and yohimbine and evaluate their combined safety profile.
results_summary: The study found a clinically significant drug-drug interaction for yohimbine when combined with clomipramine, likely due to competitive inhibition of yohimbine metabolism by clomipramine. Both drugs were safe and well-tolerated in mono- and combination therapy, with no major adverse events reported.
population_specificity: 15 healthy male subjects
study_duration: Single-dose and steady-state pharmacokinetics assessed over 24 hours
interactions: Clomipramine competitively inhibits yohimbine metabolism, likely mediated by cytochrome P450 2D6.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of yohimbine as a repurposed anticancer drug, specifically its effects on DMBA-induced oral cancer in hamsters.
results_summary: Yohimbine significantly restored detoxification enzyme activities, reduced oxidative stress markers, and downregulated inflammatory and proliferative markers (COX-2, IL-6, PCNA, cyclin D1) in DMBA-treated hamsters, suggesting anticancer potential.
population_specificity: Hamsters with DMBA-induced buccal pouch carcinogenesis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effect of yohimbine against LPS-induced myocarditis in a rat model and assess its anti-inflammatory activity in vitro.
results_summary: Yohimbine significantly reduced LPS-induced inflammatory markers, improved cardiac parameters, mitigated apoptosis in myocardial cells, and ameliorated histopathological abnormalities, partly by modulating the MAPK pathway.
population_specificity: Rats with LPS-induced myocarditis and RAW 264.7 and H9C2 cells in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the influence of yohimbine, alone and combined with hydrocortisone, on selective attention processes to fearful faces and related neuronal activation.
results_summary: The study found no differences between yohimbine and placebo groups in selective attention or neuronal activation, indicating no significant effect of yohimbine on the measured outcomes. Attentional bias toward fearful faces was observed across all groups, with related activation in the left cuneus.
population_specificity: 167 healthy men aged 18-35 years (mean age 25.23 ± 4.24 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how Yohimbine (YHB) inhibits the proliferation and migration of vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) induced by platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) and its underlying transcriptional regulatory mechanisms.
results_summary: YHB downregulated cell cycle regulatory proteins (PCNA, cyclin D1, CDK4, cyclin E) via FOXO3a modulation, reduced p-38 and mTOR phosphorylation, and significantly decreased FAK phosphorylation (especially at Y925) and paxillin expression, leading to inhibited VSMC proliferation and migration. Co-treatment with mTOR or p38 inhibitors enhanced these effects.
population_specificity: Vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) induced by PDGF.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-fibrotic, anti-inflammatory, and antioxidant effects of Yohimbine hydrochloride (YHC) in chronic liver injury models.
results_summary: YHC significantly reduced inflammatory and fibrotic markers in vitro and in vivo, mitigated oxidative stress, and improved survival in rats by modulating the JNK/Wnt/β-catenin pathway.
population_specificity: HLECs, HSC-LX2, HepG2 cells, and thioacetamide-induced hepatic fibrosis rat models.
study_duration: 5 weeks (inflammation model) and 9 weeks (fibrosis model) in rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how oxytocin affects yohimbine-induced reinstatement of ethanol-seeking behavior in female rats.
results_summary: Yohimbine significantly increased lever responses, indicating reinstatement of ethanol-seeking behavior in female rats. Oxytocin administration, both systemically and in the central amygdala, attenuated this yohimbine-induced effect.
population_specificity: Adult female rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the density of α2-adrenergic receptors (ARs) using PET imaging with 11C-yohimbine in Parkinson's disease patients compared to healthy controls.
results_summary: The study found reduced 11C-yohimbine binding in cortical regions, thalamus, and putamen in Parkinson's patients, with specific reductions linked to tremor and anxiety symptoms. These results suggest noradrenergic dysfunction in Parkinson's disease.
population_specificity: 30 Parkinson's disease patients and 30 age- and sex-matched healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify a multitargeted anticancer compound by screening phytobioactive chemicals, focusing on yohimbine's binding affinity and stability with key protein targets.
results_summary: Yohimbine exhibited the lowest docking scores (-8.3 to -10.0 kcal/mol) and stable binding with all studied protein targets, particularly ERK2, PARP1, and PIK3α, suggesting it as a potent lead molecule for anticancer therapy.
population_specificity: In silico (computational) study, no human or animal subjects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anticancer potential of yohimbine in drug-resistant oral cancer KB-ChR-8-5 cells.
results_summary: Yohimbine demonstrated dose-dependent cytotoxicity with an IC50 of 44 µM, induced apoptosis, increased ROS generation, and modulated mitochondrial membrane potential in KB-ChR-8-5 cells.
population_specificity: Drug-resistant oral cancer KB-ChR-8-5 cell lines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess yohimbine's binding phenomenon with hemoglobin and its molecular mechanism, correlating structure-function relationships for drug design.
results_summary: The study found that yohimbine successfully binds to hemoglobin with high affinity (10^5 M^-1) through static quenching, driven by hydrophobic forces and hydrogen bonding, and the interaction was spontaneous and exothermic. Structural analysis showed significant perturbation of hemoglobin upon yohimbine binding.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether yohimbine modulates long-term fear conditioning and extinction in humans by enhancing noradrenergic activity.
results_summary: Yohimbine increased salivary alpha-amylase activity, indicating enhanced noradrenergic release, and elevated fear-conditioned bradycardia and electrophysiological signatures, suggesting it strengthened fear memory consolidation.
population_specificity: 51 healthy male students explicitly aware of stimulus contingencies.
study_duration: Single administration between fear acquisition and extinction, with recall assessed 1 day later.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the efficacy of Yohimbine as a pharmacological treatment for erectile dysfunction (ED) by analyzing randomized controlled trials comparing it to placebo or no treatment.
results_summary: Yohimbine alone and in combination significantly improved erectile function compared to placebo, but alone did not significantly improve sexual function. Combined treatments showed higher efficacy in improving sexual function.
population_specificity: Patients with erectile dysfunction (ED).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate Yohimbine's antidepressant activity through molecular docking, pharmacokinetic analyses, and in silico mutational studies targeting the 5HT1A receptor.
results_summary: Yohimbine demonstrated good drug-likeness and pharmacokinetic properties, with strong docking scores and hydrogen-bond interactions with the 5HT1A receptor, suggesting substantial efficacy against MDD, though further bench studies are needed for confirmation.
population_specificity: In silico (computational) study, no human or animal subjects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the electrophysiological effects of Yohimbine on human cardiomyocytes using hiPSC-CMs to assess potential cardiotoxicity.
results_summary: Yohimbine inhibited spontaneous action potentials, prolonged action potential duration, and negatively affected sodium and calcium channel currents in hiPSC-CMs, indicating direct cardiotoxic effects not mediated by α2-adrenoceptor signaling.
population_specificity: Human-induced pluripotent stem cell-derived cardiomyocytes (hiPSC-CMs)
effective_dosage: Low doses (IC50 = 14.2 μM for INa), high doses (IC50 = 139.7 μM for ICa)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate severe poisoning and death cases associated with yohimbine use.
results_summary: The study found high concentrations of yohimbine in the blood of four poisoned individuals, with one fatality linked to extremely elevated levels (5631 ng/mL). Autopsy and toxicological analysis ruled out other causes, suggesting yohimbine poisoning as the likely cause of death.
population_specificity: Four middle-aged men (aged 47-65) suspected of yohimbine poisoning.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify new compounds derived from yohimbine with selective antagonistic activities against GPCRs relevant to cancer treatment.
results_summary: Several yohimbine analogues showed differential antagonistic activities against GPCRs, with Y7g exhibiting selective antagonism against AVPR2 (IC50 = 459 nM) and OXTR (IC50 = 1.16 µM), potentially linking its anti-cancer activity to GPCR antagonism.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate yohimbine's inhibitory effect on benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and explore its underlying mechanisms, particularly its impact on the steroid 5α-reductase pathway.
results_summary: Yohimbine significantly inhibited prostatic index increase in BPH rats (46.7–69.3% across doses) and reduced levels of key biomarkers (dihydrotestosterone, prostatic acid phosphatase, prostate-specific antigen, proliferating cell nuclear antigen, and steroid 5α-reductase), suggesting therapeutic benefits via the steroid 5α-reductase pathway.
population_specificity: Male rats with testosterone-induced BPH.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to validate two new HPLC methods for determining drugs used in treating male sexual disorders, including Yohimbine, while comparing the performance of core-shell and monolithic columns for greener chromatography.
results_summary: The study found that core-shell columns offered higher efficiency and resolution, while monolithic columns allowed greener solvent use at higher flow rates. Both methods successfully determined the drugs in pharmaceutical forms, counterfeit products, and human plasma.
population_specificity: Not specified (focused on analytical methodology, not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether yohimbine has a renoprotective effect on lipopolysaccharide (LPS)-induced acute kidney injury (AKI) in rats.
results_summary: Yohimbine treatment improved kidney function, reduced inflammatory markers (such as cytokines and iNOS), enhanced anti-inflammatory IL-10 expression, and blocked NF-κB nuclear localization. It also improved blood pressure and activated ERK/CREB phosphorylation pathways.
population_specificity: Male Sprague Dawley rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of a single acute dose of yohimbine hydrochloride on repeated anaerobic sprint ability in physically active females.
results_summary: Yohimbine significantly improved mean power, total work, and heart rate while reducing fatigue index and post-exercise lactate levels compared to placebo. It also increased epinephrine concentrations but did not affect norepinephrine or rate of perceived exertion.
population_specificity: Physically active females (n = 18)
study_duration: Acute (single dose administered 20 minutes before exercise)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the exact amounts of yohimbine free base in various formulations and validate a method for its quantification.
results_summary: The study found that all tested formulations contained yohimbine, though some had lower concentrations than labeled. A validated densitometric HPTLC method was used to measure yohimbine content after acid-base purification.
population_specificity: Not specified (study focused on formulations, not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the neural mechanisms by which yohimbine induces reinstatement of alcohol seeking and the associated patterns of brain activation.
results_summary: Yohimbine increased Fos-protein expression in stress/impulsivity centers (prefrontal cortex, extended amygdala) in a non-drug context and recruited additional brain regions (thalamus, hypothalamus, hippocampus) during alcohol-seeking reinstatement. Fos-protein correlations were stronger during reinstatement compared to home-cage administration.
population_specificity: Alcohol-experienced alcohol-preferring rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of yohimbine on neuronal spiking activity in the anterior cingulate cortex (ACC) and basolateral amygdala (BLA) between sham-lesioned and hemiparkinsonian rats.
results_summary: Yohimbine treatment (5mg/kg, SubQ) reduced neuronal spiking activity in the BLA of sham-lesioned rats but had no effect in hemiparkinsonian rats. Yohimbine did not affect ACC neuronal spiking activity in either group.
population_specificity: Anesthetized sham-lesioned and hemiparkinsonian rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Yohimbine enhances the effectiveness of virtual reality exposure therapy (VRET) for specific phobia by elevating norepinephrine and improving emotional memory.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in outcomes between VRET with Yohimbine, VRET with propranolol, and VRET with placebo, suggesting Yohimbine did not enhance therapeutic effects beyond VRET alone.
population_specificity: Fifty-six participants with specific phobia.
study_duration: Three sessions of VRET over two weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether yohimbine could augment prolonged exposure therapy for PTSD by increasing arousal during exposure and improving treatment outcomes.
results_summary: Yohimbine increased objective and subjective arousal during exposure and reduced trauma-cued heart-rate reactivity one week later. It also improved between-session habituation and depression symptoms but did not significantly affect PTSD symptoms over the course of treatment.
population_specificity: 26 males with combat-related PTSD
