study_duration: Single dose prior to first imaginal exposure, followed by standard prolonged exposure therapy

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of enteral yohimbine as a treatment for severe amitraz poisoning in a pediatric case.
results_summary: The child regained consciousness within 18 hours after yohimbine administration and was successfully weaned off mechanical ventilation, suggesting yohimbine may be effective in managing amitraz poisoning.
population_specificity: A 3-year-old child with severe amitraz poisoning.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the antagonistic potency and anti-aggregation effects of aroxyalkyl derivatives of 2-methoxyphenylpiperazine, including Yohimbine, at 5-HT2A and α2-adrenoceptors.
results_summary: Yohimbine showed moderate antagonistic effects at α2-adrenoceptors but was less potent than compound MH-77 in inhibiting collagen-stimulated platelet aggregation. It also inhibited 5-HT/adrenaline-, ADP-, or collagen-induced platelet aggregation.
population_specificity: Rat models (in vitro and in vivo)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of gonadal hormones and Yohimbine on ethanol-seeking behavior in male and female rats, focusing on reinstatement as a model of craving-like behavior.
results_summary: Yohimbine, combined with cues, induced reinstatement of ethanol seeking, but neither prior chronic nor acute hormone manipulations altered this effect. Blockade of estrogen receptors slightly reduced reinstatement in intact females.
population_specificity: Male and female rats (rodent model).
study_duration: Three weeks of operant ethanol self-administration, followed by extinction training and acute hormone manipulation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the therapeutic effects of yohimbine, alone and combined with naloxone, on PCOS-related body weight and endocrinological parameters in a rabbit model.
results_summary: Yohimbine treatment showed a descending trend in most PCOS-related parameters (luteinizing hormone, insulin) compared to the positive control, except for estradiol. Combined yohimbine and naloxone therapy improved clinical manifestations of PCOS.
population_specificity: Adult, reproductively mature female rabbits (Oryctolagus cuniculus) with induced PCOS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a novel analytical method (SPME-HPLC) for pharmacokinetic study of yohimbine in human plasma.
results_summary: The study successfully developed a PEEK tube-based SPME-HPLC method with high enrichment efficiency, wide linear range (2-1000 ng/mL), and low detection limit (0.1 ng/mL) for yohimbine analysis in plasma. The method was applied to a pharmacokinetic study, with results compared to existing methods.
population_specificity: Human plasma samples (specific population not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether berberine combined with yohimbine (BY) could reduce neutrophil tissue infiltration and multiple organ damage in septic mice, and to explore the mechanisms involved.
results_summary: BY therapy attenuated neutrophil infiltration and organ injury in septic mice, partly through IL-10-mediated inhibition of CCR2 expression in circulating neutrophils. These effects were reversed by IL-10 antibody pretreatment, though some chemokine reductions persisted.
population_specificity: Septic mice induced by cecal ligation and puncture (CLP).
study_duration: Administered 2 hours after CLP, with follow-up measurements at 6 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether yohimbine, an α2-adrenoceptor antagonist, could attenuate kidney injury and reduce renal venous norepinephrine levels in rats with acute ischaemia/reperfusion-induced kidney injury.
results_summary: Yohimbine (0.1mg/kg) significantly reduced kidney injury and renal venous norepinephrine levels compared to controls. The protective effect was linked to α2C-adrenoceptor inhibition, as selective α2C-antagonists replicated these benefits, while α2A- and α2B-antagonists did not.
population_specificity: Rats with induced acute kidney injury via renal ischaemia/reperfusion.
study_duration: Single dose administered 5 minutes prior to ischaemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the impact of yohimbine, a pharmacological stressor and alpha-2 adrenergic receptor antagonist, on executive function in cocaine-dependent men and women during cocaine cue exposure.
results_summary: Yohimbine reduced omission errors in cocaine-dependent individuals but increased commission errors in healthy controls. Cocaine-dependent women showed more omission errors and slower reaction times compared to cocaine-dependent men.
population_specificity: Cocaine-dependent men (n=12), cocaine-dependent women (n=27), control men (n=31), and control women (n=25).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects of Yohimbine hydrochloride (YCL) in collagen-induced arthritis (CIA) in Wistar rats to assess its potential as an anti-RA treatment.
results_summary: YCL significantly reduced inflammatory markers (articular elastase, LPO, catalase) and improved antioxidant levels (GSH, SOD), while also decreasing expression of proinflammatory cytokines (COX-2, TNF-α, NF-ĸB) and ameliorating joint damage in rats with CIA.
population_specificity: Wistar rats with collagen-induced arthritis (CIA).
effective_dosage: 5 and 10 mg/kg body weight, once daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the central mechanisms by which prazosin and doxazosin (alpha-1 antagonists) reduce yohimbine-induced reinstatement of alcohol seeking in rats.
results_summary: Yohimbine-induced reinstatement of alcohol seeking was significantly reduced by both ICV and systemic prazosin (50-69% decreases) and doxazosin (78% decrease). Prazosin also reduced yohimbine-induced Fos expression in key brain regions, suggesting central action.
population_specificity: Rats trained to self-administer alcohol.
effective_dosage: Yohimbine (1.25 mg/kg), prazosin (ICV: 2 and 6 nmol; systemic: 1 mg/kg), doxazosin (1.25, 2.5, and 5 mg/kg).
study_duration: Not explicitly stated in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether yohimbine enhances the antidepressant-like effects of Sanggenon G and fluoxetine in rats subjected to forced swim test-induced depression.
results_summary: Yohimbine significantly enhanced the antidepressant-like effects of both fluoxetine and Sanggenon G, reducing immobility time in rats. The effect was dose-dependent, with notable improvements at 5, 10, and 20 mg/kg for fluoxetine and at 5 and 10 mg/kg for Sanggenon G.
population_specificity: Rats subjected to forced swim test-induced depression.
effective_dosage: 5, 10, and 20 mg/kg (for fluoxetine); 5 and 10 mg/kg (for Sanggenon G).
interactions: Enhanced effects of fluoxetine and Sanggenon G when pretreated with yohimbine.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness and safety of yohimbine and guanfacine as α2-adrenoceptor ligands in reducing body mass and their anorectic activity.
results_summary: Yohimbine showed anorectic activity and significantly reduced intraperitoneal adipose tissue, with a beneficial effect on lipid profiles. However, it was less effective than guanfacine, and its α1-adrenoceptor blockade was linked to side effects but also improved lipid profiles.
population_specificity: Wistar rats with high-fat diet-induced obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether α2 adrenoceptor antagonism by yohimbine could enhance the anxiolytic-like effects of the SSRI fluoxetine in a preclinical anxiety model.
results_summary: The study found that combining yohimbine with fluoxetine produced a significantly greater reduction in water intake (an anxiolytic-like effect) than fluoxetine alone, suggesting yohimbine may enhance SSRI efficacy.
population_specificity: Rats in a schedule-induced polydipsia paradigm (a preclinical anxiety model).
study_duration: Daily administrations (exact duration not specified in the abstract).
interactions: Enhanced effects when combined with fluoxetine.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of yohimbine on anxiety-related behaviors in zebrafish larvae under normal and stressful conditions.
results_summary: Low doses of yohimbine reduced anxiety-related behaviors (anxiolytic) under normal conditions, while high doses increased anxiety (anxiogenic) in older larvae. Under stressful conditions, yohimbine generally increased anxiety-related behaviors in a dose-dependent manner.
population_specificity: AB strain zebrafish larvae at 5 and 7 days postfertilization (dpf).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether yohimbine, as an adjunct to imipramine, accelerates behavioral and neurogenic effects in the hippocampus and identify its molecular and cellular targets.
results_summary: Yohimbine combined with imipramine (Y+I) enhanced neurogenic effects and modulated genes related to intracellular signaling, stress responses, and neuropeptide pathways, similar to fast-acting electroconvulsive seizure (ECS) but distinct from chronic imipramine treatment. The combination also reduced expression of receptors linked to antidepressant action (Adra2a, Htr2c, Sstr1) and regulated key signaling pathway genes (Impa2, Dio3, Rgs4, Acer2, Dclk2, Nfkbia, Sgk1).
population_specificity: Adult rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if yohimbine, when administered after alcohol cue exposure sessions of varying durations, could alter alcohol cue-induced responding and self-administration in rats.
results_summary: The study found that neither yohimbine nor propranolol had subsequent effects on cue-induced responding or alcohol self-administration, suggesting limited efficacy in this context.
population_specificity: Rats trained to respond for alcohol in a controlled experimental setting.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the impact of yohimbine, a pharmacological stressor, on subjective, endocrine, and physiological responses to cocaine-paired cues in cocaine-dependent men and women compared to controls.
results_summary: Yohimbine increased anxiety, craving, and stress hormone levels, with stronger effects in women. It also heightened heart rate responses more in women than men, suggesting gender differences in stress-induced vulnerability to craving and relapse.
population_specificity: Cocaine-dependent men (n=32), cocaine-dependent women (n=30), control men (n=32), and control women (n=25).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining yohimbine HCL with prolonged exposure therapy could enhance treatment outcomes for veterans with PTSD.
results_summary: The abstract does not report specific results regarding yohimbine's effects, as the study is proposed rather than completed.
population_specificity: 40 veterans with PTSD
study_duration: Paired with the first session of imaginal exposure (duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether yohimbine could effectively augment exposure therapy for social anxiety disorder, particularly its impact on self-reported and clinician-rated outcomes.
results_summary: Yohimbine was well tolerated and showed faster improvement and better outcomes on self-report measures of social anxiety and depressed mood, but not on clinician-rated measures. The benefits were more pronounced in patients who reported low fear at the end of exposure exercises.
population_specificity: Adults with DSM-IV diagnosed social anxiety disorder (n = 40).
effective_dosage: 10.8 mg yohimbine HCl administered 1 hour before each of four exposure sessions.
study_duration: Four exposure sessions, with follow-up measurements at posttreatment and 1-month follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether yohimbine, as an anxiogenic drug, would increase hippocampal theta frequency in rats to assess the construct validity of the theta model of anxiety.
results_summary: Yohimbine significantly increased behavioral measures of anxiety in the elevated plus-maze but did not increase hippocampal theta frequency, contrasting with the expected neurophysiological response. This discrepancy questions the construct validity of the theta model for anxiety.
population_specificity: Urethane-anesthetized rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and validate a high-performance thin-layer chromatographic method for determining yohimbine hydrochloride in pharmaceutical preparations.
results_summary: The study successfully developed a sensitive and accurate HPTLC method for quantifying yohimbine hydrochloride, with linear calibration (80-1000 ng/spot, R²=0.9965) and effective separation from other components. Yohimbine content varied widely in tested preparations (2.3-5.2 mg/tablet in pure alkaloid products vs. 0-1.8 mg/capsule in bark supplements).
population_specificity: Pharmaceutical preparations and dietary supplements containing yohimbine or yohimbe bark.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of yohimbine on cold stress-induced erectile dysfunction in rats, comparing its efficacy with sildenafil.
results_summary: Yohimbine significantly improved sexual arousal, potency, and mating behavior in stressed rats but did not alter testosterone, FSH, LH, or cholesterol levels. It also demonstrated a dose-dependent relaxant effect on rat corpus cavernosum strips.
population_specificity: Male rats subjected to cold stress-induced erectile dysfunction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether yohimbine could reverse the protective effects of brimonidine on glutamate- and hydrogen peroxide-induced damage in rat-cultured spiral ganglion neurons.
results_summary: Yohimbine reversed the protective effects of brimonidine, indicating its role as an antagonist of α(2)-ARs in this context. The study did not assess yohimbine's standalone effects but demonstrated its interaction with brimonidine.
population_specificity: Rat-cultured spiral ganglion neurons (SGNs)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether α2-adrenoceptor inhibition with yohimbine affects islet blood flow and metabolic parameters in GK rats, a model for type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Yohimbine decreased blood glucose and increased serum insulin concentrations in GK rats but had no effect in WF rats. It also reduced islet blood flow in GK rats to levels similar to WF rats, suggesting α2-adrenoceptor overexpression may contribute to increased islet blood flow in diabetes.
population_specificity: Anesthetized GK (type 2 diabetic) and Wistar-F (control) rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether yohimbine could overcome the suppressive effects of short winter-like day lengths on male sexual behavior in rodents.
results_summary: Yohimbine treatments that increased copulatory behavior in long days were ineffective in facilitating male sexual behavior under short-day conditions, both during gonadal regression and after recrudescence. The study suggests that the brain circuit mediating sexual behavior may be less responsive to yohimbine in short days or that neurotransmitter changes differ between day lengths.
population_specificity: Male hamsters exposed to short winter-like day lengths.
study_duration: 16 weeks (gonadal regression) and 32 weeks (gonadal recrudescence) of short-day treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether yohimbine hydrochloride (YOH) enhances the effects of virtual reality exposure therapy (VRET) for fear of flying by increasing noradrenaline levels.
results_summary: Both YOH and placebo groups showed significant anxiety reduction after VRET, but YOH did not enhance treatment outcomes despite successfully increasing noradrenaline levels. The study found no evidence that YOH improved efficacy beyond VRET alone.
population_specificity: Participants meeting DSM-IV criteria for a specific phobia (fear of flying).
effective_dosage: 10 mg administered 1 hour prior to exposure sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the pharmacokinetics of yohimbine when administered alone and in combination with detomidine in horses.
results_summary: The study found that yohimbine's systemic clearance and volume of distribution decreased when administered after detomidine, leading to higher plasma concentrations. The elimination half-life of yohimbine remained unchanged, but the increased plasma concentrations could potentially cause adverse effects.
population_specificity: Nine healthy adult horses aged 9 ± 4 years and weighing 561 ± 56 kg.
study_duration: Single-dose administration with a minimum 1-week washout period between regimens.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether yohimbine, an α2A AR antagonist, could reduce the severity of endotoxin-induced acute lung injury in rats by modulating inflammatory responses.
results_summary: Yohimbine significantly improved oxygenation, reduced white blood cell counts, lowered lung histopathological scores, and decreased levels of inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-1β, IL-6) compared to the LPS-only group, suggesting it alleviates pulmonary inflammation via α2A AR blockade.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats
study_duration: Effects assessed at 6, 24, and 48 hours post-administration

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of delta opioid peptide receptors (DOP-Rs) in yohimbine-stress-induced reinstatement of ethanol-seeking behavior in rats.
results_summary: Yohimbine increased ethanol-seeking behavior in rats, an effect mediated by DOP-Rs, as pretreatment with the DOP-R antagonist SoRI-9409 reduced this reinstatement. Yohimbine also increased DOP-R-stimulated GTPγS binding in brain membranes, which was inhibited by SoRI-9409.
population_specificity: Male Long-Evans rats trained to self-administer ethanol.
study_duration: Not specified (daily 30-minute sessions until extinction criteria were met)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of yohimbine and pyridostigmine in improving orthostatic hypotension and explore potential synergistic effects when combined.
results_summary: Yohimbine significantly improved standing diastolic blood pressure and presyncopal symptoms compared to placebo, while pyridostigmine showed no significant effect. No synergistic effect was observed when the two were combined.
population_specificity: 31 patients with severe autonomic failure.
study_duration: Single administration with measurements taken 60 minutes post-dose.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of a combination of yohimbine and L-arginine (SX) in treating mild to moderate erectile dysfunction.
results_summary: The study found that SX was significantly more effective than placebo at week 4, with no significant difference in adverse events between the two groups. The conclusion was that SX is safe and effective for short-term treatment of mild to moderate ED.
population_specificity: Married males aged 25-50 with mild to moderate erectile dysfunction (IIEF scores 15-25) and a minimum 3-month history of ED.
effective_dosage: One capsule on demand (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare male and female rats on stress-induced relapse of cocaine seeking using yohimbine and examine the potential sex-specific treatment effects of allopregnanolone.
results_summary: Female rats were more resistant to extinction and showed greater reinstatement of cocaine seeking after yohimbine injections compared to males. Allopregnanolone blocked yohimbine's effect in females but not males.
population_specificity: Male and female rats
study_duration: 14-day maintenance period, followed by extinction and reinstatement testing

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether neuropeptide Y (NPY) could block yohimbine-induced reinstatement of alcohol-seeking behavior, a model of relapse.
results_summary: NPY dose-dependently blocked yohimbine-induced reinstatement of alcohol seeking but did not affect ongoing alcohol self-administration. Yohimbine and NPY both activated neuronal populations in stress- and reward-related brain regions, with additive effects.
population_specificity: Rats (animal model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how yohimbine, a pharmacological stressor, interacts with heroin-associated cues to influence relapse behavior in an animal model.
results_summary: Yohimbine alone and heroin-associated cues alone reliably reinstated heroin-seeking behavior. When yohimbine preceded cue-induced reinstatement, the response was significantly potentiated (3-4x higher than cues or yohimbine alone).
population_specificity: Rats in an animal model of heroin relapse.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to document severe acute neurotoxic and hemodynamic effects following a large ingestion of yohimbine in a bodybuilder.
results_summary: A 37-year-old bodybuilder experienced severe neurotoxic effects (loss of consciousness, seizures, extreme hypertension) after ingesting 5 g of yohimbine, requiring intensive medical intervention. Elevated blood levels of yohimbine were detected, with a mean half-life of 2 hours.
population_specificity: 37-year-old male bodybuilder
study_duration: Acute effects observed within 2 hours; monitoring continued for 22 hours

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the antagonistic effects of yohimbine and atipamezole on xylazine-induced diuresis in dogs.
results_summary: Yohimbine effectively reversed xylazine-induced diuresis, showing greater potency than atipamezole, though its effects were not dose-dependent. Both drugs similarly reversed xylazine-induced changes in urine and plasma parameters without significantly altering hormonal profiles.
population_specificity: Five healthy male beagles.
study_duration: Single administration with measurements over 24 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the potency of yohimbine hydrochloride (YH) and MRS2179 in inhibiting collagen-epinephrine interaction in patients with acute coronary syndrome (ACS) receiving dual antiplatelet therapy.
results_summary: YH showed greater potency in inhibiting collagen-epinephrine interaction compared to MRS2179, with lower molar concentrations required for blocking the effect. The study suggests alpha2A-adrenoreceptors play a major role in this interaction.
population_specificity: Patients with acute coronary syndrome (ACS) receiving aspirin and clopidogrel therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the pharmacological effects of Yohimbine on noradrenergic activity in the brain and its potential role in anxiety-related behaviors.
results_summary: Systemic administration of Yohimbine increased noradrenergic cell firing in the locus coeruleus and catecholamine release in the amygdala, effects that were blocked by prior administration of clonidine or anxiolytics like chlordiazepoxide and buspirone, suggesting Yohimbine's anxiogenic effects are mediated by alpha-2 adrenoceptors.
population_specificity: Anaesthetized rats
interactions: Clonidine, chlordiazepoxide, and buspirone counteract Yohimbine's effects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether yohimbine enhances fear extinction learning in rats and whether this effect persists during drug-free retention tests.
results_summary: Yohimbine dose-dependently reduced freezing during extinction training but did not improve retention of extinction learning when tested drug-free. The highest dose reduced bar-press suppression, but effects were not sustained post-treatment.
population_specificity: Rats (animal study)
study_duration: 3 days (conditioning on day 1, extinction training on days 2 and 3)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether yohimbine hydrochloride enhances the effectiveness of exposure therapy for claustrophobia in humans.
results_summary: Both yohimbine and placebo groups improved post-treatment, but the yohimbine group showed significantly greater reduction in peak fear at one-week follow-up, with large to very large effect sizes across measures.
population_specificity: Adults with marked claustrophobic fear (71% undergraduate students, 29% community volunteers).
effective_dosage: 10.8 mg prior to each exposure session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether repeated exposure to yohimbine during extinction training affects the rate of extinction and subsequent reinstatement of cocaine seeking in rats.
results_summary: Rats treated with yohimbine before extinction sessions showed slower extinction and reduced yohimbine-induced reinstatement of cocaine seeking, but footshock-induced reinstatement was unaffected.
population_specificity: Rats trained to self-administer cocaine
study_duration: Five days of extinction training with yohimbine, followed by additional extinction without yohimbine

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the CRF1 receptor antagonist antalarmin could attenuate yohimbine-induced increases in alcohol self-administration and relapse behavior in rats.
results_summary: Yohimbine increased alcohol self-administration and reinstated alcohol seeking after extinction, effects that were attenuated by antalarmin. Antalarmin alone had no impact on alcohol self-administration or extinction responding, nor did it affect yohimbine-induced corticosterone release.
population_specificity: Alcohol-experienced rats
study_duration: Several weeks of training, followed by 13 days of extinction testing

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of the alpha(2)-adrenergic receptor (alpha(2)-AR) in extinction of cocaine-conditioned place preference (CPP) and glutamatergic transmission in the BNST, specifically examining the effects of yohimbine.
results_summary: Yohimbine impaired cocaine CPP extinction in mice, an effect not replicated by the more selective alpha(2)-AR antagonist atipamezole. Yohimbine also depressed glutamatergic transmission in the BNST, independent of alpha(2A)-ARs.
population_specificity: C57BL/6J mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Ro60-0175 could reduce cocaine-seeking behavior triggered by yohimbine, a pharmacological stressor, and drug-associated cues.
results_summary: Yohimbine (1 mg/kg) reinstated cocaine-seeking behavior in rats, and this effect was dose-dependently reduced by Ro60-0175. The reinstatement was context-specific, occurring only in the original self-administration environment.
population_specificity: Rats trained to self-administer cocaine.
study_duration: Not specified for yohimbine alone; Ro60-0175 effects were tested over 8 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether yohimbine enhances the antidepressant effects of fluoxetine or venlafaxine in a mouse model of depression.
results_summary: Yohimbine potentiated the antidepressant effects of both fluoxetine and venlafaxine, significantly reducing immobility time in the forced swim test compared to either drug alone. The study suggests alpha(2)-receptor involvement in the mechanism of these antidepressants.
population_specificity: Male Laca strain mice
study_duration: Single administration (15 min before antidepressant drugs)
interactions: Enhanced effects of fluoxetine and venlafaxine

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of yohimbine in treating orgasmic dysfunction in men.
results_summary: Of the 29 patients, 16 achieved orgasm and ejaculation, with an additional three succeeding with vibrator assistance. Side effects were not severe enough to discontinue treatment, and two patients fathered children post-treatment.
population_specificity: Men with orgasmic dysfunction (primary complete, primary incomplete, or secondary).
effective_dosage: Initial 20-mg dose, with optional titration at home.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether yohimbine reverses morphine-induced effects on the hippocampus by activating pleiotrophin/midkine pathways.
results_summary: Chronic yohimbine administration increased midkine mRNA levels, and when combined with morphine, it had summatory effects on midkine upregulation, suggesting a role in preventing opioid-induced neuroadaptations. Pleiotrophin expression remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Rats (animal study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of intrathecal yohimbine on locomotion in intact rats, specifically assessing dose-dependent impairment and tachyphylaxis.
results_summary: Yohimbine caused dose-dependent hindlimb locomotor impairment, ranging from transient paralysis (200 µg/20 µL) to trunk instability (50 µg/20 µL). Repetitive high and medium doses led to tachyphylaxis, while low doses did not.
population_specificity: Intact rats
effective_dosage: 50, 100, and 200 µg/20 µL, administered every 48 hours
study_duration: Multiple injections over an unspecified period (tachyphylaxis observed by the third injection)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether noradrenergic (NA) inputs to the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis (BNST) are necessary for Yohimbine's effects on the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis, feeding inhibition, and conditioned flavor avoidance in rats.
results_summary: Yohimbine inhibited food intake and supported conditioned flavor avoidance independently of NA inputs to the BNST, but HPA axis activation was significantly blunted in rats with NA input lesions. NA neurons from the medulla provided collateral inputs to the BNST and paraventricular hypothalamus, contributing to Fos expression and HPA activation after Yohimbine treatment.
population_specificity: Rats (specifically, those with NA input lesions in the BNST).
study_duration: Not specified (terminal experiment conducted 90-120 min post-injection).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether yohimbine, an anxiogenic alpha2-noradrenergic receptor antagonist, enhances cocaine-seeking behavior in rats when combined with cocaine-associated cues.
results_summary: Yohimbine alone or cues alone reinstated cocaine-seeking behavior (3-4 times extinction levels), but combining yohimbine with cues greatly potentiated responding (10-13 times extinction levels). Plasma corticosterone levels increased during cocaine self-administration but did not correlate with lever-pressing behavior during reinstatement.
population_specificity: Rats with a history of cocaine self-administration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether yohimbine administration activates autonomic parameters and salivary alpha-amylase (sAA) via adrenergic mechanisms, suggesting sAA as an indirect indicator of central sympathetic system activity.
results_summary: Yohimbine significantly increased sAA activity, blood pressure, salivary flow rate, and catecholamine levels compared to placebo, but no significant correlations were found between sAA and catecholamines. The results suggest yohimbine activates both autonomic parameters and sAA via adrenergic mechanisms.
population_specificity: 13 healthy males aged 20-28 years.
study_duration: Not specified (short-term, based on repeated sampling before and after injection).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the mechanism by which yohimbine inhibits spontaneous activity of prefrontal neurons in rats, specifically its action through alpha2A/D-receptor subtypes.
results_summary: The study found that yohimbine inhibits spontaneous activity of prefrontal neurons via alpha2A/D-receptor mechanisms, an effect mimicked by BRL44408 and blocked by imiloxan, suggesting increased norepinephrine release and postsynaptic inhibition through alpha2B-receptors.
population_specificity: Rats (prefrontal neurons)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the binding affinities and functional subtype selectivities of tethered yohimbine ligands for human alpha(2)-AR subtypes, specifically assessing whether the second pharmacophore is essential for selectivity.
results_summary: The study found that tethered yohimbine analogs exhibited higher binding affinities and selectivity for the alpha(2C)-AR subtype compared to alpha(2A)- and alpha(2B)-ARs, with some analogs showing significant fold selectivities. Functional assays confirmed the antagonist activities and selectivity profiles of these compounds.
population_specificity: Human alpha(2)-AR subtypes expressed in Chinese hamster ovary cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether yohimbine, an alpha-2 adrenoceptor antagonist, could induce stress-related relapse to palatable food seeking in rats on a restricted diet.
results_summary: Yohimbine injections reliably reinstated food-seeking behavior in rats after extinction, an effect attenuated by the CRF1 receptor antagonist antalarmin, suggesting CRF involvement in stress-induced relapse.
population_specificity: Rats on a restricted diet (75-80% of daily standard food).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether alpha-2 adrenergic activity is involved in the cognitive-enhancing effects of Ginkgo biloba extract by examining yohimbine's impact on prefrontal cognitive function in rats.
results_summary: Yohimbine reduced choice accuracy in a delayed alternation task in a dose- and delay-dependent manner. Ginkgo biloba extract prevented this reduction at higher doses (50, 100, or 200 mg/kg), suggesting its cognitive effects may involve alpha-2-adrenoceptors.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the duration of yohimbine's stimulatory effects on ejaculation in male dogs and its interaction with clonidine.
results_summary: Yohimbine (0.1 mg/kg) significantly increased ejaculated semen volume and shortened ejaculation onset for up to 5 hours, but effects diminished by 8-24 hours. It also blocked clonidine-induced ejaculatory inhibition when administered 1-5 hours prior.
population_specificity: Male dogs
study_duration: Effects assessed at 0.5, 1, 3, 5, 8, and 24 hours post-administration

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine whether yohimbine, an alpha(2)-adrenoceptor antagonist, could protect against GFAP alterations caused by chronic morphine treatment.
results_summary: Yohimbine pretreatment reduced morphine-induced GFAP upregulation in key brain regions, suggesting it mitigates astroglial reactions linked to chronic morphine exposure. The findings indicate alpha(2)-adrenergic mechanisms may play a role in morphine-induced brain pathology.
population_specificity: Rats treated with chronic morphine
effective_dosage: 2 mg kg(-1), intraperitoneally, 30 min before each morphine injection

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether yohimbine antagonizes the antidepressant-like effects of tramadol and desipramine in a mouse model of depression.
results_summary: Yohimbine (2 mg/kg, i.p.) antagonized the antidepressant-like effects of both tramadol and desipramine in mice subjected to unpredictable chronic mild stress, suggesting its role in modulating the noradrenergic system.
population_specificity: BALB/c mice subjected to unpredictable chronic mild stress.
study_duration: Not specified (treatment duration not detailed in abstract).
interactions: Antagonized effects of tramadol and desipramine.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and safety of NMI 861 (containing yohimbine and L-arginine) in healthy males, including its interaction with intravenous nitroglycerine (GTN).
results_summary: NMI 861 was well tolerated with no significant adverse reactions. It showed a small but significant difference in systolic blood pressure compared to placebo but no significant interaction with GTN-induced hypotension.
population_specificity: Healthy male subjects (16 in the first study, 12 in the second).
effective_dosage: 7.7 mg yohimbine tartrate combined with 6 g L-arginine glutamate (single oral dose).
interactions: No significant hypotensive interaction with intravenous GTN detected.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe a paradoxical adverse effect of yohimbine in a patient with CREST syndrome using it for erectile dysfunction.
results_summary: The study found that yohimbine worsened Raynaud's phenomenon in a patient with CREST syndrome, despite its intended use for erectile dysfunction. The case highlights a potential contraindication in certain populations.
population_specificity: A patient with CREST syndrome (calcinosis, Raynaud's phenomenon, esophageal dysfunction, sclerodactyly, and telangiectasia).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of yohimbine with sildenafil, phentolamine, and L-arginine on rabbit corpus cavernosum smooth muscle relaxation and nitrergic transmission.
results_summary: Yohimbine did not show significant effects on electrical field stimulation-induced relaxation of rabbit corpus cavernosum and had a lower potency (ED50 = 35.84 ± 2.24 µM) compared to sildenafil and phentolamine. It reduced phenylephrine-induced tone but was less effective than other tested drugs.
population_specificity: Rabbit corpus cavernosum (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and effects of yohimbine versus atipamezole in reversing amitraz intoxication in dogs.
results_summary: Yohimbine effectively reversed all amitraz-induced alterations but caused significant cardiorespiratory side effects like tachycardia and tachypnea. Atipamezole was also effective but with fewer cardiorespiratory effects, suggesting it as a potential alternative.
population_specificity: Thirty dogs divided into three groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effects of iontophoretically applied yohimbine on prefrontal cortical neurons in rats to understand its antagonistic and hyperpolarizing effects on presynaptic alpha2 receptors.
results_summary: Yohimbine simulated the inhibitory effect of norepinephrine on PFC neurons, acting primarily on presynaptic alpha2 receptors rather than postsynaptic ones. The effect was not blocked by known alpha1 or postsynaptic alpha2 receptor agents, suggesting a specific mechanism of action.
population_specificity: Rat prefrontal cortical (PFC) neurons in vivo

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the specificity of regional brain Fos activation in response to cues associated with the anxiogenic drug yohimbine and compare it to activation patterns seen with rewarding drugs.
results_summary: Yohimbine elicited a progressively sensitized locomotor response in rats and, upon re-exposure to the paired environment without the drug, conditioned increases in motor activity were observed. Fos expression increased in the basolateral amygdala but remained unchanged in the prefrontal cortex, contrasting with patterns seen with rewarding drugs.
population_specificity: Rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Yohimbine hydrochloride in enhancing arterial blood inflow to the penis and its efficacy in treating erectile dysfunction.
results_summary: Yohimbine hydrochloride at a single dose of 5-10 mg improved arterial blood inflow to the penis, and a mean daily dose of 15-20 mg was effective in treating erectile dysfunction, with response rates ranging from 38% to 84% depending on the dysfunction type. Occasional side effects were noted but could be managed by dose reduction.
population_specificity: 153 men with erectile dysfunction (results available for 140).
effective_dosage: Single dose of 5-10 mg; mean daily dose of 15-20 mg.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of yohimbine on REM sleep disturbances in clomipramine-induced depressed rats.
results_summary: Yohimbine microinjection significantly reduced the total duration and number of REM sleep episodes compared to control saline injections, indicating its potential to attenuate REM sleep disturbances in this model.
population_specificity: Clomipramine-induced depressed rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining Yohimbine with L-arginine enhances subjective and physiological sexual arousal in postmenopausal women with Female Sexual Arousal Disorder.
results_summary: The combination of L-arginine and Yohimbine significantly increased vaginal pulse amplitude responses at 60 minutes post-administration compared to placebo, though subjective arousal reports did not differ between treatment groups.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women with Female Sexual Arousal Disorder.
effective_dosage: 6 mg Yohimbine HCl (single dose per session).
study_duration: Acute administration (effects measured at 30, 60, and 90 minutes post-dose).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the evidence for Yohimbine's efficacy in treating erectile dysfunction based on randomized-controlled trials.
results_summary: Yohimbine was among the most common ingredients in ED supplements, but the abstract does not specify its individual efficacy results. Overall, 19% of ingredients received strong positive evidence (A grade), while 68% had contradicting, negative, or lacking evidence (C or D grades).
population_specificity: Not specified (general male population seeking ED or testosterone supplements).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the prevalence and severity of yohimbine-related adverse drug events reported to the California Poison Control System between 2000 and 2006.
results_summary: The study found a substantial increase in yohimbine-associated adverse events, primarily involving herbal products, with common effects including gastrointestinal distress, tachycardia, anxiety/agitation, and hypertension. Yohimbine exposures were linked to more severe outcomes and higher healthcare facility management needs compared to average substance exposures.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18 and older who were symptomatic after yohimbine exposure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of zeaxanthin dipalmitate (ZD)-enriched emulsion on gut microbiota and inflammation in a mouse model of colitis.
results_summary: Supplementation with ZD-enriched emulsion improved serum indicators, reduced pro-inflammatory cytokines, increased tight junction proteins, and modulated gut microbiota, particularly enriching beneficial genera like Akkermansia and Lactobacillus. The emulsion showed potential health-promoting roles.
population_specificity: Mice with dextran sulfate sodium (DSS)-induced colitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Zeaxanthin (Zea) combined with exercise (Exc) had therapeutic effects on obesity induced by a high-fat diet (HFD) in rats.
results_summary: Zea, Exc, and their combination reduced body weight gain, triacylglycerol, glucose, total cholesterol, and nitric oxide levels while increasing catalase and insulin compared to the HFD group. The combination of Zea and Exc showed better effects than either intervention alone.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats fed a high-fat diet to induce obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of zeaxanthin, alone and in combination with brassinolide, on physiological metabolism, chlorophyll fluorescence, and nutritional quality of radish sprouts during cold storage.
results_summary: The study found that zeaxanthin combined with brassinolide improved hypocotyl length, fresh weight, secondary metabolites, nutritional content, glutathione levels, PSII photoprotection, and antioxidant capacity in radish sprouts compared to zeaxanthin alone. The combination also outperformed brassinolide alone in enhancing biomass and antioxidant capacity.
population_specificity: Radish sprouts stored at 4 °C.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether zeaxanthin could attenuate allergic asthma in mice by modulating the p38 MAPK/β-catenin signaling pathway.
results_summary: Zeaxanthin significantly reduced inflammatory markers (IgE, IL-4, IL-5, IL-13, eotaxin), oxidative stress (MDA, SOD, GST, GSH), and collagen deposition in OVA-induced asthma mice, while suppressing the p38 MAPK/β-catenin pathway.
population_specificity: BALB/c nude mice with OVA-induced allergic asthma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of the central noradrenergic system in the ejaculatory reflex of rats and evaluate the effects of yohimbine on this reflex.
results_summary: Yohimbine enhanced noradrenergic transmission, inducing an ejaculatory genital motor pattern (GMP) without urethral stimulation, which was blocked by clonidine. Clonidine itself induced a GMP via alpha(1)-adrenoceptors, and prazosin attenuated the yohimbine-induced response, suggesting alpha(1)-adrenoceptor involvement.
population_specificity: Male sexually experienced Wistar rats subjected to coital reflex exhaustion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Zeaxanthin (ZEA) pre-treatment could prevent or defer cognitive defects and neurovascular damage induced by Aβ1-42 in rats.
results_summary: ZEA pre-treatment prevented learning and memory impairment, maintained cerebrovascular ultrastructure, regulated redox state, reduced ET-1 levels, and stabilized Aβ homeostasis by modulating Aβ transport receptors and inflammatory cytokines.
population_specificity: Rats (divided into control, Aβ1-42, ZEA, and ZEA + Aβ groups).
